verses.text: After Jesus finished all these sayings, he said to his disciples,
verses.comment: This marks the conclusion of Jesus’ major teaching section in Matthew, transitioning into the Passion narrative.

verses.text: "You know that after two days the Passover is coming, and the Son of Man will be handed over to be crucified."
verses.comment: Jesus directly predicts his approaching death at Passover, connecting his sacrifice with the Passover lamb (Exodus 12:6). Calling himself ‘Son of Man’ alludes to Daniel 7:13-14, indicating messianic and possibly divine identity.

verses.text: Then the chief priests and the elders of the people gathered in the courtyard of the high priest, whose name was Caiaphas,
verses.comment: The religious leaders plotting show the mounting opposition to Jesus, fulfilled in detail as he had predicted.

verses.text: and they plotted together to arrest Jesus by stealth and kill him.
verses.comment: Opposition to the Anointed One (Christ) fulfills Psalm 2:2. Secrecy highlights their fear of public backlash.

verses.text: "But not during the festival," they said, "lest there be an uproar among the people."
verses.comment: Their concern shows how popular Jesus was among the people, and their fear underscores the political and religious tension in Jerusalem.

verses.text: Now Jesus was in Bethany, at the house of Simon the leper.
verses.comment: Bethany was the home of friends Mary, Martha, and Lazarus. Simon the leper may have been healed by Jesus, a detail showing his outreach to the marginalized.

verses.text: A woman came to him with an alabaster jar of very expensive ointment, and she poured it on his head while he reclined at table.
verses.comment: Anointing with oil symbolizes royal dignity and preparation for burial (see Mark 14:8). Women’s significant roles appear throughout Jesus' ministry.

verses.text: But when the disciples saw this, they were indignant and said, "Why this waste?"
verses.comment: The disciples’ reaction shows their misunderstanding of the significance of Jesus’ coming sacrifice.

verses.text: "This could have been sold for a lot and given to the poor."
verses.comment: Generosity to the poor is always encouraged, but here a unique moment has a higher spiritual significance.

verses.text: But Jesus, aware of this, said to them, "Why do you trouble the woman? She has done a beautiful thing to me.
verses.comment: Jesus affirms the value of her act, indicating that devotion to him is a unique good.

verses.text: "For you always have the poor with you, but you will not always have me."
verses.comment: Jesus references Deuteronomy 15:11. The uniqueness of his physical presence is emphasized, paving the way for future modes of his presence in the Church.

verses.text: "For in pouring this ointment on my body, she has done it to prepare me for burial."
verses.comment: Jesus links the anointing to his imminent death, emphasizing the necessity and glory of his sacrificial work.

verses.text: "Truly I tell you, wherever this gospel is proclaimed in the whole world, what she has done will also be told in memory of her."
verses.comment: This is remarkable in its universality, foreshadowing the global church and the commemoration of acts of devotion as examples for the faithful.

verses.text: Then one of the twelve, called Judas Iscariot, went to the chief priests
verses.comment: Judas’ betrayal is the fulfillment of prophecy (Ps. 41:9), highlighting the mystery of free will and God’s providence.

verses.text: and said, “What will you give me if I deliver him over to you?” And they paid him thirty silver coins.
verses.comment: Thirty pieces of silver fulfills Zechariah 11:12, symbolizing both Jesus’ rejection and his role as the suffering servant.

verses.text: From then on he sought an opportunity to betray him.
verses.comment: Here the narrative turns from plotting to action; Judas’ intent sets the stage for the Passion.

verses.text: On the first day of Unleavened Bread, the disciples came to Jesus, saying, "Where do you want us to prepare for you to eat the Passover?"
verses.comment: The Passover context is central, prefiguring Jesus as the true Paschal Lamb (1 Cor. 5:7), and demonstrating the continuity between Old and New Covenants.

verses.text: He said, "Go into the city to a certain man and say to him, 'The Teacher says, My time is near. I will keep the Passover at your house with my disciples.'"
verses.comment: The phrase ‘my time is near’ signifies Jesus’ awareness and sovereign control over the coming events. The preparation alludes to the sacred traditions around Passover meals.

verses.text: So the disciples did as Jesus had directed them and prepared the Passover.
verses.comment: Obedience to Jesus’ instruction highlights the importance of apostolic authority in the preparatory actions for His Last Supper.

verses.text: When evening came, he was reclining at table with the twelve.
verses.comment: The group’s intimacy foreshadows the unity of believers and the institution about to occur.

verses.text: And as they were eating, he said, "Truly, I tell you, one of you will betray me."
verses.comment: Jesus’ precise foreknowledge fulfills prophecy and displays his divinity, showing he is not a victim, but willingly embraces his mission (see John 10:17-18).

verses.text: Greatly distressed, each one began to say to him, "Surely not I, Lord?"
verses.comment: The disciples’ reaction shows their self-examination, a key element in preparing to receive Christ with pure motives—a practice maintained in the ritual life of the church.

verses.text: He answered, "The one who has dipped his hand in the bowl with me will betray me."
verses.comment: Sharing the bowl signifies deep fellowship. Betrayal from such intimacy intensifies the offense, echoing Psalm 41:9.

verses.text: "The Son of Man goes as it is written of him, but woe to that man by whom the Son of Man is betrayed! It would have been better for that man if he had not been born."
verses.comment: The ‘as it is written’ echoes fulfillment of suffering servant prophecies (Isaiah 53), underscoring both God’s sovereignty and human responsibility.

verses.text: Then Judas, who would betray him, said, "Surely not I, Rabbi?" Jesus said to him, "You have said it."
verses.comment: Jesus’ reply directly identifies Judas’ role, and the use of ‘Rabbi’ instead of ‘Lord’ may hint at Judas’ lesser faith.

verses.text: Now as they were eating, Jesus took bread, and after blessing it, he broke it and gave it to the disciples and said, "Take, eat; this is my body."
verses.comment: Jesus institutes the central act of Christian worship here. The plain sense—‘this is my body’—forms the basis of the Church’s belief in the true presence of Christ in the Eucharist, as later articulated by Paul (1 Cor. 11: 23-29).

verses.text: And he took a cup, and when he had given thanks, he gave it to them, saying, "Drink from it, all of you;"
verses.comment: Sharing the cup is symbolic of the covenant ritual (Exod. 24:8). Noteworthy is the command for all to partake, anticipating full sacramental participation.

verses.text: "for this is my blood of the covenant, which is poured out for many for the forgiveness of sins."
verses.comment: Jesus affirms the New Covenant in his blood, echoing Exodus 24:8. The forgiveness of sins underscores the sacrificial and redemptive nature of his act—a reality made present for believers through liturgical participation.

verses.text: "I tell you, I will not drink again of this fruit of the vine until that day when I drink it new with you in my Father's kingdom."
verses.comment: Jesus points to the heavenly consummation of the banquet. The idea of ongoing fellowship and the kingdom’s fullness points to the continuing reality of the Eucharist and eschatological hope.

verses.text: When they had sung a hymn, they went out to the Mount of Olives.
verses.comment: The Passover meal traditionally ended with singing the Hallel Psalms (Ps. 113-118). The move to the Mount of Olives sets the scene for Jesus’ agony.

verses.text: Then Jesus said to them, "You will all fall away because of me this night. For it is written, 'I will strike the shepherd, and the sheep of the flock will be scattered.'"
verses.comment: Jesus refers to Zechariah, showing his death is part of God’s plan. The scattering indicates disciples’ weakness, but also foreshadows their later restoration.

verses.text: "But after I am raised up, I will go before you to Galilee."
verses.comment: Jesus predicts his resurrection and continued leadership of his followers. Galilee signifies a place of new beginnings and mission.

verses.text: Peter answered him, "Even if everyone else falls away because of you, I will never fall away."
verses.comment: Peter’s confidence sets up the coming theme of repentance and restoration after failure—a pattern for Christian life.

verses.text: Jesus said to him, "Truly I tell you, this very night, before the rooster crows, you will deny me three times."
verses.comment: Jesus’ foreknowledge is evidence of his prophetic and divine wisdom.

verses.text: Peter said to him, "Even if I must die with you, I will not deny you!" And all the disciples said the same.
verses.comment: The disciples’ boldness contrasts with their coming weakness, highlighting the need for God’s grace even among the closest followers of Jesus.

verses.text: Then Jesus went with them to a place called Gethsemane, and he said to his disciples, "Sit here, while I go over there and pray."
verses.comment: Gethsemane (meaning ‘oil press’) symbolizes Jesus being pressed by suffering. His prayer exemplifies recourse to the Father in trial.

verses.text: He took with him Peter and the two sons of Zebedee, and began to be sorrowful and distressed.
verses.comment: Peter, James, and John—his inner circle—also witnessed the Transfiguration. Here, they witness his agony, preserving the reality of Jesus’ humanity.

verses.text: Then he said to them, "My soul is very sorrowful, even to death; stay here and watch with me."
verses.comment: Jesus’ deep sorrow shows his real human nature and his solidarity with all who suffer.

verses.text: And going a little farther, he fell on his face and prayed, saying, "My Father, if it is possible, let this cup pass from me; yet not as I will, but as you will."
verses.comment: Jesus perfectly submits his human will to the Father. The ‘cup’ stands for suffering and divine wrath; his prayer models obedience and abandonment to God’s will.

verses.text: He came to the disciples and found them sleeping. He said to Peter, "So, could you not watch with me one hour?"
verses.comment: The disciples’ weakness reflects the frailty of human nature and the necessity of grace to persevere in prayer.

verses.text: "Watch and pray that you may not enter into temptation. The spirit indeed is willing, but the flesh is weak."
verses.comment: Jesus teaches the necessity of prayer to resist temptation, acknowledging the tension between spiritual resolve and bodily weakness.

verses.text: Again, for the second time, he went away and prayed, "My Father, if this cannot pass unless I drink it, your will be done."
verses.comment: Jesus teaches perfect submission to God’s will, echoing the Lord’s Prayer. His human will is united with the Father’s divine plan, a mystery that later theological developments would emphasize.

verses.text: Again he came and found them sleeping, for their eyes were heavy.
verses.comment: Repeated failure to stay awake continues the theme of human frailty countered by Christ’s faithfulness.

verses.text: So, leaving them again, he went away and prayed for the third time, saying the same words once more.
verses.comment: The triple repetition underscores the seriousness of Jesus’ agony. The number three often represents completeness in biblical symbolism.

verses.text: Then he came to the disciples and said to them, "Sleep and take your rest later on. See, the hour is at hand, and the Son of Man is betrayed into the hands of sinners."
verses.comment: Reference to ‘the hour’ signifies the fulfillment of prophetic timing, and ‘Son of Man’ further underscores Jesus’ Messianic role.

verses.text: "Rise, let us be going; see, my betrayer is at hand."
verses.comment: Jesus goes willingly to his arrest, showing his authority and obedience to the divine plan.

verses.text: While he was still speaking, Judas, one of the twelve, arrived, and with him a large crowd with swords and clubs, sent by the chief priests and elders of the people.
verses.comment: A disciple leads those who oppose Jesus, fulfilling Psalm 41:9 regarding betrayal by a close friend.

verses.text: Now the betrayer had given them a sign, saying, "The one I kiss is the man; seize him."
verses.comment: A kiss, a sign of friendship, is perverted into a signal for betrayal.

verses.text: Immediately he came up to Jesus and said, "Greetings, Rabbi!" and kissed him.
verses.comment: ‘Rabbi’ once more highlights Judas’s different relationship to Jesus compared to the other disciples, who call him ‘Lord’.

verses.text: Jesus said to him, "Friend, do what you came to do." Then they came up and laid hands on Jesus and seized him.
verses.comment: Jesus’ gentle address to Judas (‘Friend’) exemplifies love towards one’s betrayer, and his acceptance of arrest confirms his purposeful embrace of suffering.

verses.text: And behold, one of those with Jesus stretched out his hand, drew his sword, and struck the servant of the high priest, cutting off his ear.
verses.comment: John identifies this disciple as Peter. His attempt at violence contrasts sharply with Jesus’ teaching on peace and non-resistance.

verses.text: Then Jesus said to him, "Put your sword back in its place. For all who take the sword will perish by the sword."
verses.comment: Jesus rebukes violence, recalling Genesis 9:6. The Kingdom advances not by force but by sacrificial love.

verses.text: "Do you think that I cannot appeal to my Father, and he will at once send me more than twelve legions of angels?"
verses.comment: Jesus displays his divine authority. His submission to suffering is not from weakness but from loving obedience.

verses.text: "But how then would the Scriptures be fulfilled, that it must be so?"
verses.comment: Everything unfolds according to God’s plan revealed in Scriptures, demonstrating the inseparable connection between Christ’s mission and the Old Testament.

verses.text: At that hour Jesus said to the crowds, "Have you come out as against a robber, with swords and clubs to capture me? Day after day I sat teaching in the temple, and you did not seize me."
verses.comment: Jesus contrasts the secretive violence against him with his open ministry in the temple, emphasizing his innocence.

verses.text: But all this has happened that the writings of the prophets might be fulfilled." Then all the disciples left him and fled.
verses.comment: Jesus is abandoned as foretold by the prophets, but his faithfulness perseveres even in solitude.

verses.text: Those who had seized Jesus led him away to Caiaphas the high priest, where the scribes and elders had gathered.
verses.comment: Jesus stands before the religious authorities, fulfilling his role as both high priest and sacrificial victim.

verses.text: Peter followed him at a distance, as far as the courtyard of the high priest. He entered and sat with the guards to see how it would end.
verses.comment: Peter’s hesitant following prepares for his threefold denial and later conversion, highlighting the role of repentance.

verses.text: Now the chief priests and the whole council sought false testimony against Jesus, to put him to death,
verses.comment: The miscarriage of justice is highlighted by the leaders’ reliance on false witnesses.

verses.text: but they found none, though many false witnesses came forward. At last two came forward
verses.comment: The requirement of two witnesses (Deut. 19:15) is met only by distortion, underlining the innocence of Jesus.

verses.text: and said, "This man said, 'I am able to destroy the temple of God and rebuild it in three days.'"
verses.comment: They misunderstand (or twist) Jesus’ prophetic statement about the temple, which actually refers to his body—implying resurrection and the new temple being Christ himself.

verses.text: And the high priest stood up and said, "Have you no answer to make? What is it that these men testify against you?"
verses.comment: Jesus’ silence fulfills Isaiah 53:7 about the suffering servant who ‘opened not his mouth’.

verses.text: But Jesus remained silent. And the high priest said to him, "I adjure you by the living God, tell us if you are the Christ, the Son of God."
verses.comment: The demand for a direct answer is a legal oath. Jesus’ identity as the Christ and Son of God is the crux of the trial, staking a claim to divinity (cf. Daniel 7:13-14).

verses.text: Jesus said to him, "You have said so. But I tell you, from now on you will see the Son of Man seated at the right hand of Power and coming on the clouds of heaven."
verses.comment: Jesus explicitly associates himself with Daniel 7 and Psalm 110, both messianic and divine texts, confirming his claim to share God’s authority and status. This is widely recognized as a direct claim to divinity.

verses.text: Then the high priest tore his robes and said, "He has uttered blasphemy! What further witnesses do we need? You have now heard his blasphemy."
verses.comment: Tearing robes is a sign of declared blasphemy in Jewish law. The charge of blasphemy only makes sense if Jesus’ words are understood as a claim to divinity.

verses.text: "What is your judgment?" They answered, "He deserves death."
verses.comment: According to Leviticus 24:16, blasphemy was punishable by death, which the leaders now call for.

verses.text: Then they spat in his face and struck him. Some slapped him,
verses.comment: Isaiah 50:6 predicted the servant would be spat upon and struck, underscoring fulfillment of prophecy.

verses.text: saying, "Prophesy to us, you Christ! Who is it that struck you?"
verses.comment: Their mockery ironically affirms Jesus’ office as prophet, priest, and king.

verses.text: Now Peter was sitting outside in the courtyard. A servant girl came up to him and said, "You also were with Jesus the Galilean."
verses.comment: Peter’s denial is key to understanding the need for restoration and forgiveness among Christ’s followers.

verses.text: But he denied it before them all, saying, "I do not know what you mean."
verses.comment: First denial—Peter’s fear mirrors the fallibility of human leaders, who are restored by grace.

verses.text: When he went out to the gateway, another servant girl saw him and said to those who were there, "This man was with Jesus of Nazareth."
verses.comment: Peter’s denials escalate in a wider public setting.

verses.text: Again he denied it, with an oath: "I do not know the man."
verses.comment: Swearing an oath increases the gravity of Peter’s denial, drawing attention to his human weakness.

verses.text: A little later those standing there came up and said to Peter, “Surely you too are one of them, for your accent gives you away.”
verses.comment: Peter is recognized by his Galilean accent, showing the powerful public witness even simple characteristics can offer.

verses.text: Then he began to curse and swear, "I do not know the man!" Immediately the rooster crowed.
verses.comment: The third and most vigorous denial is met with immediate fulfillment of Jesus’ prophecy, illustrating Christ’s prophetic and divine authority.

verses.text: And Peter remembered the word Jesus had spoken, "Before the rooster crows, you will deny me three times." And he went out and wept bitterly.
verses.comment: Peter’s tears mark the beginning of his repentance. The restoration of Peter after failure becomes a foundation for understanding forgiveness and apostolic leadership (see John 21:15-17).
